GPyOpt

Tune your algorithms and design your wetlab experiments
Fork On GitHub
Downloads:
  • ZIP
  • TAR

    GPyOpt

    -- Python open-source library for Bayesian Optimization --

    -- Developed by the Machine Learning group of the Univeristy of Sheffield --

    -- Based on GPy , python framework for Gaussian process modeling--

    Why?

    With GPyOpt you can:

  • Solve global optimization problems with Bayesian optimization.

  • Import all GPy functionalities: Choose between a large variety of kernels, kernel combinations, likelihoods, models, etc.

  • Run optimization methods in parallel and make use of all your computational resources. Design batches of wetlab experiments.

  • Solve Big-Data optimization problems using sparse Gaussian process.

    • Installation

    The simplest way to install GPyOpt is using pip. Be sure that all the dependencies (GPy, numpy, scipy, matplotlib, pylab, random) are also installed.

    Ubuntu users can do: 
    >> sudo apt-get install python-pip
>> pip install GPyOpt

    GPyOpt is available for Mac users. Write (if you use homebew): 
    >> sudo brew install python-pip
>> pip install GPyOpt

    On Windows, we recommend the anaconda python distribution. From the anaconda command prompt type: 
    >> pip install GPyOpt

    Install from source and contribute: You can install GPyOpt from source. To fork the repository click fork on the GPyOpt project page. To contribute to the repository, clone it and add it to your pythonpath and send a pull request 
    >> git clone git@github.com:SheffieldML/GPy.git ~/SheffieldML
echo 'PYTHONPATH=$PYTHONPATH:~/SheffieldML' >> ~/.bashrc

    Documentation

    General users: check the collection of notebooks.

    Code developers: check the online documentation.

    GPyOpt in...

    GPyOpt is free and runs under BSD 3-clause license. Please cite 

    @Misc{gpy2015,
  author =   {The GPyOpt authors},
  title =    {GPyOpt: A Bayesian Optimization framework in python},
  howpublished = {\url{http://github.com/SheffieldML/GPyOpt}},
  year = {2015}
}
    if you use the package. If you contact us, we will be very happy to include you in the following list of GPyOpt applications:

  • Javier Gonz√°lez, Joseph Longworth, David James, Neil Lawrence. Bayesian Optimization for synthetic gene design. The Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS'14), Workshop in Bayesian Optimization, 2014.

    • Contact

    The code of GPyOpt is under active development. We'd love to here of any bugs you have found. Please submit any issue or question through our GPyOpt issues page.
